An integral part of the fight for racial equality, Medgar Wiley Evers, was born July 2, 1925, in
			 Decatur, Mississippi, to James and Jessie Evers.

Faithfully serving his country, Medgar Evers willingly left high school to join the Army at the
			 start of World War II.

After the conclusion of the war, Mr. Evers returned home to Mississippi, completed high school,
			 enrolled in Alcorn Agricultural and Mechanical College (presently known as
			 Alcorn State University) and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Business
			 Administration.

While at Alcorn State University, Medgar Evers met and married fellow Alcorn student, Myrlie
			 Beasley, of Vicksburg, Mississippi.

Upon graduation, Myrlie and Medgar Evers moved to Mound Bayou, Mississippi, where Medgar held a job
			 with Magnolia Mutual Life Insurance Company, and began establishing local
			 chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
			 (

Having been so moved by the immense suffering of African-Americans in Mississippi, Medgar Evers
			 felt compelled to fight to change the circumstances and challenges facing
			 them and, in 1954, Medgar Evers became the first known African-American to
			 apply to the University of Mississippi School of Law. Mr. Evers was denied
			 enrollment.
In 1954, Medgar Evers became the first Field Secretary for the Mississippi chapter of the NAACP.

In the capacities of his new position Medgar Evers hosted numerous voter registration efforts in
			 Mississippi and, as a result of these activities, received numerous
			 threats against his life.

Despite these threats, Mr. Evers carried on his work with dedication and courage, organizing
			 rallies, building membership within the NAACP, and traveling around the
			 country educating the public on the fight for Civil Rights.

Medgar and Myrlie Evers’ passion for quality education for all children led them to file suit
			 against the Jackson, Mississippi, public school system gaining him
			 attention with the national media as a leader of the Civil Rights Movement
			 in Mississippi.

As a result of his continued and ongoing efforts—rallies, sit-ins, and protests—to stand up for the
			 rights of African-Americans in Mississippi, Mr. Evers was arrested,
			 beaten, and jailed with his due process rights denied.

The senseless and abhorrent violence against Mr. Evers reached its pinnacle on June 12, 1963, when
			 he was violently shot in front of his home and died shortly afterwards in
			 a local hospital, mere hours after President John F. Kennedy had made a
			 national televised speech from the Oval Office calling for full racial
			 integration in America. The Civil Rights Act was enacted the following
			 year.
As a veteran, Evers was buried with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery.

On June 23, 1963, Byron De La Beckwith, a member of the White Citizens’ Council, was arrested for
			 Evers’ murder, but juries in 1964, composed solely of white men, twice
			 deadlocked on De La Beckwith’s guilt, resulting in mistrials.

Following two trials resulting in acquittal, in 1990, Mrs. Evers convinced Mississippi prosecutors
			 to reopen Medgar Evers’ murder case, and a new trial led to the conviction
			 and life imprisonment of Medgar Evers’ killer in 1994.
